content:
I know that enomoto haruhisa made a complete list of tactic. However, I thought it would be useful for beginners to have a list of frequently used tactics that can be looked up by situation of use.

I couldn't find an existing one (so I made one myself, but it's in Japanese).

Would you like to create such a thing? Or is there already one?

I just want to put in a link to the complete list you mentioned: https://github.com/haruhisa-enomoto/mathlib4-all-tactics/blob/main/all-tactics.md
There's also some tactics in the "cheat sheet": https://raw.githubusercontent.com/madvorak/lean4-cheatsheet/main/lean-tactics.pdf

I also couldn't find such a thing so I made one myself for my Lean 3 course here https://www.ma.imperial.ac.uk/~buzzard/xena/formalising-mathematics-2023/Part_C/Part_C.html ; I will be updating this to Lean 4 but not until December.

Note that my documentation also often contains extensive examples, an overview of the tactic explained in layman's terms etc. I found that these were important for the students. Feel free to use any of the material or the ideas in it, if you want to make a Lean 4 version. The list can also be considered as a list of what I think are "the most important tactics".

If someone does this (I'd help if there's something to do for a beginner), it would also be nice to put it in some "more official" place (manual, one of the books, lean-lang.org, etc.). I've had lots of "site not found" results clicking university website links in papers recently.
Yes, indeed I will be sorely tempted to nuke those Lean 3 pages once I have ported my course to Lean 4.

My tactic list is here: https://lean-ja.github.io/tactic-cheetsheet
I'm going to use the list Kevin made as a guide to add more tactic.
Thank you!
Asei Inoue has marked this topic as resolved.
